factual_background: A claim was filed in July 1994 regarding the rightful occupants of the Chief and Councillor offices of the Lower Similkameen Indian Band (LSIB).
A counterclaim was filed in September 1994 seeking to nullify the election of the current office holders.

Prior to the counterclaim, an action was initiated in the Supreme Court of British Columbia in June 1994 seeking injunctive relief related to bank account access and performance of duties by the LSIB Council.
The British Columbia Supreme Court determined it lacked jurisdiction and suggested the Federal Court was the appropriate venue.
The plaintiffs then filed a statement of claim in the Federal Court in July 1994 seeking damages, declaratory, and injunctive relief, which was amended multiple times.
Interlocutory injunctive relief was denied by the Federal Court in July 1994 due to a lack of evidence of irreparable harm.
A Prothonotary of the Federal Court struck portions of the amended statement of claim in April 1996, finding certain relief requests outside the court's jurisdiction.
The plaintiffs sought a declaration confirming Barbara Allison as Chief and Pauline Terbasket as Councillor.
The defendants (counterclaimants) sought a declaration that the March 29, 1994, election was null and void and requested a new election.
Disputes arose regarding the appointment of the Electoral and Returning Officers prior to the election.
There were allegations concerning the establishment of an Appeal Board before the election.
The form of the ballots used in the election was contested.
The conduct of scrutineers during the election was questioned.
The ballots were destroyed by the Electoral Officer on June 1, 1994, after the 30-day appeal period had passed.
A document submitted as an appeal was deemed not to meet the requirements of the LSIB Custom Election Regulations.

Applicants: The election of the plaintiffs (Barbara Allison as Chief and Pauline Terbasket as Councillor) was valid.
The defendants improperly challenged the election results.
Any violations of the LSIB Custom Election Regulations were not substantial enough to invalidate the election.
The destruction of the ballots was lawful because no valid appeal had been filed.
The court has jurisdiction to hear the claim.
The counterclaim should be struck as it discloses no reasonable cause of action and/or the court lacks jurisdiction.
The counterclaim was improperly framed as an action rather than an application for judicial review.
The limitation period for a judicial review application has expired.
The defendants were not sued in their capacity as the LSIB Council.
Respondents: The election was conducted in violation of eleven provisions of the LSIB Custom Election Regulations.
The Returning Officer was not properly appointed.
The Appeal Board was not established as required by the Regulations.
The electors list was not properly ratified.
Scrutineers acted improperly by attempting to influence voters.
The ballots were improperly destroyed before the appeal period had fully elapsed.
A document submitted to the Band Office constituted a valid appeal.
The election should be declared null and void.

court_analysis: The central issue was jurisdiction. The court determined it lacked jurisdiction over both the main claim and the counterclaim, primarily because the proper avenue for challenging the Band Council election was through judicial review under the Federal Court Act, not as a standard action. The plaintiffs had initially filed in British Columbia Supreme Court, which correctly deferred to the Federal Court, but then pursued an action in Federal Court instead of a judicial review application.

The court applied the three-part test from *In Re Ottawa*, finding no statutory grant of jurisdiction in either the Indian Act or the Federal Court Act to hear the claim as an action. Sections 17 and 18 of the Federal Court Act were considered and rejected as bases for jurisdiction; Section 17 didn't apply as the defendants weren't acting as agents of the Crown, and Section 18 required a judicial review application, which wasn't filed.

The court examined Sections 25 and 44 of the Federal Court Act, concluding they didn't independently grant jurisdiction. It found that Section 25 required a lack of jurisdiction in any other court, which wasn't the case as the BC Supreme Court had initially been seized of the matter, and Section 44 couldn't be used to create jurisdiction where none was explicitly granted.

Regarding the merits of the case (though ultimately not decided due to lack of jurisdiction), the court meticulously analyzed alleged violations of the Lower Similkameen Indian Bands Custom Election Regulations. It found several technical violations occurred (regarding the appointment of the Returning Officer, establishment of an Appeal Board, ballot form, and assistance to an elder).

However, the court reasoned that these violations, individually and collectively, didn't necessarily invalidate the election. It applied a standard akin to grounds for appeal under the Regulations, finding none of the violations were substantial enough to have affected the election result. The court emphasized that the violations didn't meet the threshold of 'corrupt practice' or a violation 'that might have affected the result'.

The court specifically addressed the destruction of the ballots, finding it lawful because the 30-day appeal period had passed and no valid appeal had been filed. The court distinguished a properly filed appeal from a petition or minutes of a meeting, concluding the document filed didn't meet the requirements of the Regulations.

The court weighed the evidence presented regarding the alleged regulatory breaches, finding the Electoral Officer's testimony credible and the evidence supporting the violations, where found, to be sufficient. However, it consistently applied the legal principle that technical violations do not automatically invalidate an election if they did not impact the outcome.
